displayed_text: Family Member: But do you know right away after one or two? Doctor: I would say probably after two or three you’d know if it’s working. Family Member: By that time, would we be able to go to Germany within a month? Doctor: I don’t know. Patient: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: All we’ve got is a maybe. Family Member: Can’t be sure? Doctor: Well, let me explore, so I’ve got a couple of threads I’ve got to explore a little more. Patient: Thank you. I appreciate that. Doctor: So let’s uh- Patient: So we’re off the trial now? Doctor: Yeah. We’re off the trial. We’ll probably just want to see a PSA in another month off the testosterone. That may be complicated because you may, because we’re working to go somewhere else so, it may not be that useful for us because it’s not like you’re going to be on- Healthcare Professional: Is it thirty days as before? In those terms I don’t know-

Patient: I haven’t had chemo there. Doctor: But I’m talking scans. Patient: Scans. Yeah I’ve had scans at Hospital B and also Hospital C at O____ and also the Hospital A, so in M____. So you know it doesn’t make any difference really to me, yeah. Doctor: Great, I just want to make sure that they can be compared so that we can get a sense of what’s changed- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: because if everything’s stable even though your PSA is going up, we might wait longer. If the pictures show more cancer and your PSA is higher Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: you know and then that’s the information that says okay, what do we do next? Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know say I don’t like any of those trials that (names person) Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Yeah, well I’m in favor of the trials. Family Member: There are a lot more side effects with the trials.

Family Member: Prostate. Patient: For prostate. (Chuckles) Doctor: So in the end you’re taking the blood pressure medicine and the Vitamin D. Patient: Correct. Doctor: That’s it. Patient: That’s it. Doctor: No other medicines for pain, anything else for the allergies – Patient: No. Doctor: Or vitamins? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. And when you were in the hospital, did they put any tubes or anything in, anything of that you still have. Patient: Yes, they put catheter in and uh they gave me I.V. at the beginning and made sure the catheter was out.

Family Member: I’m sorry; say that one more time. You say it’s two? What are the two again? Doctor: The -the two general like avenues that we could go; one is radiotherapy to target that lymph node. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And we have a trial to do that through H__. And the other one is to skip the radiotherapy and go directly to hormone therapy. And then we have a trial looking to see whether combining something with hormone therapy is better than hormone therapy alone. Patient: Uh hum. Family Member: Well what is the something? Doctor: Something is an oral medication. It’s a new oral hormonal therapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s a second hormone therapy that given in connection with the injection of hormone therapy we believe may produce better outcomes than just injecting the hormone by itself. Patient: But even with that, that’s still just to slow it down; it’s not to cure anything. It’s kind of take it to add a little bit more Doctor: That’s correct. Everything that we have discussed today frankly is not really curative in terms of its potential. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Mm Hmm. Doctor: Um. So, let me, uh, check in with I_ to see if she needs to follow with you, uh, because we’ll just stay on drug for now. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I put the order in for the blood test. I need to just check to make sure that, with the holiday, that if I draw it, it’s not gonna get lost or be not usable because, uh, nobody’s here to work on it. Patient: Right. Doctor: They only run the test once a week. So, if they’re aware it’s coming today and they run it next Monday, then you’re golden. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, and then, we will set up when you need to come back, but I want you to take a look at these two, read them. We’ll know the AR-V7, hopefully within a week’s time. If that’s positive, then that would be this one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And if it’s negative, it could be that one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or, if it was positive, you could still do that one. Um.

Patient: Well, will they tell you, uh, if I went down there and spent a couple of days and had the testing done-. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Will they tell you, uh, if it’s needed? Would they tell if it’s needed or not in lieu of that? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Because I can ask. They won’t show me the films, but they have a special radiologist read it, and they come back to me and tell me if you are likely to go on the study or not. Because if your cancer doesn’t have that antigen, it’s pointless to go on the medication. Patient: Right. It can’t- Doctor: So then we wouldn’t move forward with the treatment. Family Member: Do you have the results of today’s draw, blood draw? Doctor: I was told that he did not have blood drawn. Did he have it? Family Member: Yeah. Oh, yeah. Doctor: Yeah. No. I don’t, then. I’ll, uh, check. I’ll bring you the results. I don’t think I have a PSA back. Family Member: Oh. Right. Doctor: But, uh-

Patient: Legs, mostly the legs, a little bit in the back, but I wanted to address the fatigue. That’s really… Doctor: Yeah, you just feel wiped out? Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Is that still a reaction from radiation six months ago? Doctor: No. Family Member: No, He shouldn’t have any effects from the radiation at this point? Doctor: No, I mean the only sort of culprit is untreated prostate cancer. You know if I had to sort of go back and we go a round of a bunch of pills Patient: Right. Doctor: radiation but that time has passed and I’m just gonna recap where we are so we have a plan. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I told you you’re making me work hard. Patient: I know. Doctor: But I’ve been thinking about you since we can’t get these trials to gel and I told the gals over there I said listen the minute we’re kind of fumbling around, stop, back here. Because we have to reset in our ways because we’re not losing time but I hate not having a plan and you guys hate not having a plan.

Patient: Why did you say it wouldn’t be – you just don’t think they work? Doctor: Well just in all the other patients that have sort of done that, they need to do it with something else. It’s just not strong enough. Patient: Okay, yeah, okay. I can’t say it goes away you know Doctor: Mm hmm. Patient: maybe it calms me down Doctor: Yeah. Patient: and something like that too, but nothing that I’ve had right now and I, I, I I’m not consistent with it. Doctor: Sure. Patient: It’s just something that we’ve tried – Doctor: Right. Patient: - been recommended that we try and I think we brought it up but… Doctor: Yeah. You know cancer is cancer, it’s got its own set of pain.

Patient: But it seemed like I, would have, I was degenerating pretty quickly for you know? For all the bone scans I’ve had… Doctor: Yeah. Yes. Patient: Somebody would have seen that somewhere. Doctor: No. I think it’s just crappy cancer not controlled. You know? Patient: And Uh. Yeah. Doctor: There’s, there’s the uh oh this is really going to be in trouble. We got that fixed. But it’s the bigger picture. Patient: You know uh you know and I feel I actually am you know doc I’m not running today but I’m getting around better. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: I’ve, I’ve seen the, you know the steady increase. Doctor: Yep. Patient: Uh, you know, little dips on certain days. Doctor: Yeah.

Patient: What time would it be? Doctor: I don’t know. What time do you prefer? Family Member: Not Friday because you’re helping me with my health fair. Doctor: Fair enough. Patient: Uh how about um… Family Member: Thursday you’re seeing P in the morning. Patient: Yeah. Could we do it Thursday afternoon? Doctor: Sure, yeah. Family Member: It’s just an echo… Patient: How long does it take – to do that ? Doctor: It’s about, not a very long time, but it would mean that I would just need to, we would need to coordinate the echo appointment and all that- that’s why I’m just asking you for Patient: Thursday afternoon.

Family Member: They have different skin. Doctor: Yeah. (laughs) Doctor: Yeah, that part of it is funny because --- Alright, April seventeenth, the big day, we’ll get your PSA test. Are you, where do you do your PSA test? Patient: Right here. Doctor: Right here? Family Member: Uh. Patient: I, yeah, I, um, for now on, I’m trying to do them here. I don’t want to --- Doctor: Are we doin’ it on the same day or are you coming in early or? Family Member: We should – they want you to come in early so they can have something – Patient: The appointment for the twenty-fifth, she wanted me to come in a few days earlier. The nurse was saying --- Family Member: A week early. Or Doctor: The same would be true for me in April, if you could do it early?

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.3 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::3 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.strongly disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.::: strongly disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Postgraduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Postgraduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: Yeah I quit Lupron for that reason. Doctor: And you're just like, oh, man, I can't do it. Patient: So, what was the other doctor’s name? Doctor: J____. Family Member: J____. Patient: He asked about Lupron. He said Aligard. I said it’s the same thing. It’s not. Doctor: You’re right. Chemically, we do it to say this is what's happening Patient: Right. Doctor: - to your testosterone but everyone reacts to the different preparations differently. Patient: The Lupron just knocked me for a loop. They wanted me to be on Lupron for three years, and after a year, I told him I'd rather die. Doctor: Yeah, because it was terrible. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Positive as in good news? Or – Doctor: No, that you’ve got a mutation. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And, so, it’s kinda letting the genie out of the bottle a little bit once I tell you the results. Because, it has, you know, significance for your family. Family Member: And that’s what I was going to ask you. Patient: Hey! I want to know. Doctor: Okay. So, there’s a gene called BRCA2 which is – Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Associated with prostate and breast cancer. I’ll write it down for you. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Um, that your – you have a mutation that you’ve inherited. What does that mean? Um. Well, we know that BRCA2 can be, um, a predisposition to getting prostate cancer. Patient: Well, I should tell you that -- I think it happened since I saw you – my brother was diagnosed.

Family Member: You know, I think that was the last refill. Let’s check it. Doctor: I think he needs to see us uh… Family Member: I think he’s gonna need more today. Healthcare Professional: Maybe S__ was waiting? Doctor: Yeah. Walgreens, Walmart, Healthcare Professional: Walmart pharmacy (phone dialing) Doctor: Oh you’re gonna call them and ask, perfect. Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. I will be back. I have to have S__ check and see but next time I’m gonna check your sugar so come and in fasting to get you blood work. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Then you can eat. Okay? Patient: Okay.

Patient: anyway so so, with that one I continue on the Xtandi with uh, um… Doctor: Yeah. Patient: That’s not the PARP inhibitor? Doctor: Correct. And both medications would be provided by the study. Patient: I don’t know if my insurance would cover the Xtandi and the Xtandi is ten thousand dollars a month. Doctor: Yeah so I think chances are you insurance will cover it. Okay? Patient: But that’s a pretty significant consideration. Doctor: Yes oh absolutely and you know you have the exact indication for requiring Xtandi now. My concern is is it worth it because the Xtandi really did take us too far in terms of giving you control from the cancer. So honestly for the Lynparza I would really push for getting the Lynparza… Patient: The Lynparza is the uh inhibitor? Doctor: Is the pills. The PARP inhibitor. Yes. For the BRCA mutation. Patient: And without the Xtandi? Doctor: Correct.
